title: Melissa May
text:
Hi! My name is Melissa May and I am currently a student at Colorado State University completing her final semester as an undergraduate. I am majoring in Ecosystem Science and Sustainability and minoring in Political Science. My research interests lie at the intersection of environmental data science, ecosystem analysis, and natural resource policy.
Since moving to Colorado in 2018, I’ve been captivated by the state’s diverse ecosystems and am committed to using data-driven approaches to support conservation and sustainable management. I’m particularly interested in how geospatial analysis, data science, and policy implementation can work together to address complex environmental challenges.
This portfolio showcases my academic projects, research experience, and evolving skills in environmental data science and GIS.

title: Projects & Coursework
text:
This graduate-level course provided comprehensive training in environmental data science using R and open-source tools. Throughout the semester, I developed skills across data manipulation, statistical analysis, geospatial methods, and reproducible research workflows.
Core Skills Developed:

Data Wrangling & Manipulation - Mastered tidyverse functions including mutate(), select(), filter(), piping operators, group_by(), and summarize() for efficient data transformation
Data Visualization - Created quality graphics using ggplot2 with advanced customization through packages like ggthemes, RColorBrewer, viridis, ggdark, and plotly for interactive visualizations
Statistical Analysis - Conducted t-tests, ANOVA, correlation analyses, simple and multiple linear regression, and power analyses using tools like rstatix
Geospatial Analysis in R - Performed spatial data analysis and created geospatial visualizations using R’s spatial ecosystem
API Integration & Data Acquisition - Retrieved data programmatically using httr, jsonlite, and dataRetrieval packages to access USGS and other environmental databases
Version Control & Collaboration - Implemented Git and GitHub workflows including pull requests, debugging strategies, and collaborative coding practices
Reproducible Research - Generated dynamic reports and documentation using R Markdown and Quarto

Datasets Analyzed:
Worked with diverse environmental datasets including Larimer County census data, USGS stream gages and streamflow records, vertebrate survey data, North Temperate Lakes LTER air temperature and ice cover time series, Palmer Penguins ecological data, and numerous other ecological and environmental datasets.
Technical Tools:
Extensive experience with R packages including tidyverse, palmerpenguins, rmarkdown, ggthemes, RColorBrewer, viridis, ggdark, plotly, lterdatasampler, rstatix, httr, jsonlite, and dataRetrieval, among many others.




This professional development and research methods course focused on building essential skills for careers in ecosystem science and sustainability while exploring carbon management and field research techniques.
Professional Development Components:

Crafted effective elevator pitches and refined resume writing for environmental careers
Developed networking strategies and built professional online presence
Enhanced communication skills for academic and professional settings

Research & Field Experience:

CSU Mountain Campus Field Work (August 2025) - Participated in intensive field sampling at CSU’s Mountain Campus, collecting ecological data and conducting on-site environmental measurements
Forest Carbon Sequestration - Analyzed carbon storage dynamics in forest ecosystems and evaluated management strategies for climate mitigation
Carbon Management & Soil Monitoring - Studied soil carbon monitoring techniques and carbon management practices for sustainable land use

This course bridged academic training with practical career preparation while providing hands-on experience in field ecology and carbon science.




Advanced coursework in geospatial analysis using ArcGIS Pro, focusing on practical applications for wildlife management and conservation planning.
Capstone Project: Wolverine Reintroduction Site Analysis
Conducted a comprehensive spatial analysis to identify suitable wolverine reintroduction sites in Grand County, Colorado. This project integrated multiple environmental criteria to support Colorado Parks and Wildlife’s wolverine recovery efforts.
Analysis Components:

Multi-Criteria Habitat Modeling - Combined elevation (≥2,743m), persistent spring snowpack (April 15-May 14), and human disturbance buffers (≥1km from roads) to identify suitable habitat
Raster Analysis - Created and combined binary suitability rasters using raster multiplication in ArcGIS Pro
Land Cover Analysis - Extracted and analyzed land cover statistics using National Land Cover Database data

Key Findings:

Identified 463.66 km² of suitable wolverine habitat in Grand County (9.7% of total county area)
Suitable habitat characterized by high-elevation ecosystems: 36.6% evergreen forest, 33.6% shrub/scrub, 15.3% grassland
Average elevation of suitable areas: 3,425 meters (range: 2,744-4,121m)
Minimal human development (<0.1%) in suitable zones, indicating preserved wilderness character

Technical Skills:

Spatial data integration from multiple sources (USGS 3DEP elevation, MODIS-derived snowpack, USGS transportation, NLCD land cover)
Buffer analysis and proximity modeling
Raster calculation and overlay analysis
Professional cartographic design and one-pager production

This analysis provides a data-driven framework for wildlife managers to select specific release sites for Colorado’s wolverine reintroduction program.

Analyzing Participation Patterns Across Citizen Science Projects on CitSci.org
Conducted data analysis research on user engagement patterns in citizen science, collaborating with Dr. Greg Newman, co-creator of the CitSci.org platform.
Research Activities:

Analyzed user participation patterns across diverse citizen science projects on the CitSci platform
Performed statistical analysis of project types, user engagement metrics, and collaboration levels
Developed hypotheses examining how project characteristics (tags, difficulty levels, recommended age groups) influence participation rates
Collaborated with platform developers to improve data classification systems and enhance user experience
Contributed to platform redesign efforts aimed at increasing project accessibility and engagement

Impact:
Research findings informed improvements to the CitSci.org user interface and project categorization system, making the platform more intuitive for future citizen science initiatives.

title: About
text:
How I Got Here
I was born and raised in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, where I developed a deep love for the outdoors early on. My family took frequent trips to the Florida Keys, St. Augustine, and Orlando, and we spent lots of time fishing, boating, going to the beach, and just being outside. These experiences gave me an appreciation for nature long before I ever considered studying it.
Growing up near the Florida Everglades also played a big role in shaping my perspective. My elementary school was built on filled-in swamp land, and we took field trips to learn about the Everglades’ ecosystems and their significance to Florida. Even though I didn’t realize it at the time, these experiences helped me understand the importance of biodiversity and conservation – ideas that would later influence my academic and career path.
I didn’t start out studying Ecosystem Science and Sustainability. Initially, I planned to major in Psychology, but I realized it just wasn’t the right fit. I decided to explore Environmental Science and Political Science, and everything seemed to click. By the time I transferred to Colorado State University, I knew I wanted to focus my studies on the intersection of environmental policy and sustainability.
Since moving to Colorado in 2018, I’ve only become more passionate about environmental issues. After completing my undergraduate degree, I continued at CSU to pursue a Master’s degree in Ecosystem Science and Sustainability. My graduate coursework has deepened my technical skills in environmental data science, geospatial analysis, and ecosystem modeling, while my continued interest in policy and community engagement ensures I approach environmental challenges from multiple perspectives. I’m particularly interested in bridging the gap between scientific research and real-world application, ensuring that sustainability efforts are both data-driven and accessible to diverse communities.

title: About
text:
My Interests & Passions
Over the years, my interests have expanded to encompass the technical, social, and political dimensions of environmental science. Some key areas that drive my work include:
Environmental Data Science & Geospatial Analysis
My graduate studies have given me the technical skills to analyze complex environmental datasets and create meaningful visualizations that inform decision-making. I’m fascinated by how data science tools – from statistical modeling to GIS – can reveal patterns in ecosystems and help us understand environmental change. Whether it’s analyzing wildlife habitat suitability, monitoring climate trends, or evaluating land use impacts, I believe that robust data analysis is essential for effective environmental management.
Biodiversity and Conservation
I’ve always been interested in ecosystems and the role that biodiversity plays in environmental health. Learning more about nutrient cycling and ecosystem resilience at CSU has deepened my understanding of how interconnected the world is. I’m particularly interested in how we can use spatial analysis and data-driven approaches to balance conservation with human land use, and how science can inform evidence-based environmental policy.
Environmental Justice and Policy
One of the most critical aspects of sustainability is the idea that it isn’t just about science – it’s also about people. Global climate change and resource management are deeply political issues, and the communities most affected by environmental challenges are often those with the least power to influence solutions. I’m passionate about ensuring that sustainability efforts are equitable and that marginalized communities always have a voice in climate solutions.
Community Engagement and Science Communication
Ecosystem Science isn’t just about research – it’s about making information accessible and involving people in creating tangible solutions. I love opportunities to bridge the gap between academic research and its real-world application, whether that’s through outreach, education, or policy work. My experience analyzing citizen science participation patterns has reinforced my belief that inclusive, accessible science leads to better outcomes for both researchers and communities.

title: About
text:
My Work & Experience
Technical Skills
My coursework has equipped me with advanced technical skills in environmental data science. Through courses in Environmental Data Science (ESS 523A), I’ve mastered R programming for data manipulation, statistical analysis, and visualization. I’ve worked with diverse environmental datasets from USGS stream gages to LTER ecological time series, developing skills in API integration, reproducible research workflows, and collaborative coding with Git and GitHub.
In my GIS coursework (NR 319), I conducted a comprehensive spatial analysis of wolverine reintroduction sites in Colorado, integrating multiple environmental criteria to support wildlife management decisions. This project combined my technical GIS skills with my passion for conservation, demonstrating how geospatial analysis can inform real-world conservation efforts.
Natural Resource Ecology Laboratory
Since October 2023, I’ve worked at the Natural Resource Ecology Laboratory as Site Content Manager and Communications Coordinator. I’ve had the opportunity to interview esteemed scientists and create content that makes complex research accessible to diverse audiences. Through managing social media, developing website content, and collaborating with other CSU departments and statewide organizations, I’ve strengthened my science communication skills and reinforced my passion for bridging science and policy.
Research Experience
During my participation in CSU’s SUPER program (Fall 2024 - Spring 2025), I conducted data analysis research on citizen science participation patterns in collaboration with Dr. Greg Newman, co-creator of CitSci.org. This experience deepened my understanding of how project design influences public engagement in science and contributed to platform improvements that make citizen science more accessible.
Field Experience
Through my Integrated Ecosystem/Sustainability Analysis course (ESS 500), I participated in field sampling at CSU’s Mountain Campus, collecting ecological data and gaining hands-on experience with field research methods. This experience, combined with my data science skills, has given me a comprehensive toolkit for approaching environmental research from field collection through analysis and communication.

title: About
text:
What’s Next?
As I progress through my career, I’m excited to continue building my skills at the intersection of environmental data science, policy, and community engagement. I’m particularly interested in opportunities that allow me to apply technical analysis skills to real-world conservation and sustainability challenges while ensuring that solutions are equitable and community-centered.
The environmental challenges we face are complex, but they also present opportunities for interdisciplinary collaboration, innovation, and meaningful change. Whether through spatial analysis that informs wildlife conservation, data visualization that makes climate trends accessible, or research that centers community voices in environmental decision-making, I want my work to create tangible, positive impacts.
There’s still so much to learn, and that’s what excites me the most. I’m looking forward to continuing to grow in this field, learning from others, and contributing to solutions that are both scientifically rigorous and socially just.
